column14: Too much focus on being innovative rather than doing the right thing right and focusing on the quality over being the first. AMD has little man complex and the culture is over 40 years old acting in this manner is very toxic. AMD appears in a tailspin of poor decisions.

column13: Unmatched IP, brilliant new and young CEO, ambitious roadmaps, paving the way on \"Semi-custom\" SoCs for big customers.
column14: Lots of change, competing with Intel is like fighting a gorilla on steroids who makes up all the rules of the fight. But Intel increasingly less relevant to AMD's future.

column13: Great people to work with. Some good managers that actually do care. Relaxed and flexible work environment.
column14: After loosing CPU and GPU leadership trying to diversify without much success. Waisting time changing directions every few months resulting in too many canceled projects. New upper management lined up their pockets but didn't do anything good for the company apart from laying off good people every year or promising things will get better but never do. No training opportunities.

column13: There is work-life balance, the company makes exciting products, the people at AMD (worker bee level) are great, there is a general laid-back vibe and people trust one another
column14: Lack of transparency, mostly white management (white boys network mostly), no due attention given to diversity and minority managers, no career path. A senior VP actually said \"I only trust white managers!\"

column13:
If you know what you are doing you will do well.
Benefits are above average.  Profit Sharing is nice when it's available.
Pay is above normal for high achievers.
Flex work, relaxed atmosphere (like more silcon valley companies)
column14: Usually means longer hours necessary\r\nUnsteady company finances means ups and downs regular in a couple years time\r\nIt's a perenial underdog (this is usally a plus for those working there)

column13: Interesting design problems\r\nGreat base level talent in some parts of the company
column14:
Management has become increasingly focused on internal politics 
Very long hours are expected  
Tops-down decision making has caused some of the top talent to leave - or be let go for disagreeing  
Lackluster company performance has made for inconsistent bonus payouts and frequent layoffs

column13: - great place to learn technical skills\r\n- work culture is very informal, you can get involved in many different things\r\n-  higher management is easily approachable
column14:
- easy to get stuck in a bad role for long time
- no promotions
- company takes advantage of the location (orlando); keeps the salaries low
- signs of desperation quite evident

column13: Ability to work from home, friendly coworkers
column14: Management is poor, pay is average but bonuses are lousy (if they ever occur).  The company has been in a tailspin which has accelerated in the last year.  There is much dissatisfaction and concern among coworkers about the company's viablility.  Also poor recognition of effort regarding promotions.

column13: Lots of great technology which is needed by industry. People are great to work & the work environment is very suitable. Work-life balance is not always achieved but there are pockets which can be used.
column14: Short of overall money, causing serious cuts in investment that could be the future. Hard decision but the company makes it to survive. Poor executions have always been hammered by Wall Street. \r\n\r\nCompany's stability hurts the creativity from individuals.

column13:
Many good things about this company, including:

-  People
-  Projects
-  Competitive Salaries
-  No micro-management
column14: There is only one big negative:  The company is having financial issues and is doing on-going restructuring and layoffs.  Unfortunately, the only way you find out people are gone is when your email to them (and their boss?) goes unanswered.

column13:
Worked in AMD Research in Bellevue
Excellent work culture
Complete freedom to work on things we like
No micromanagement
column14: Not  so competitive salary\r\nInstability as a whole for AMD

column13: Lots of room to grow, great management
column14: Some times you feel like your in a rudderless ship, hard to find a path to take,

column13: AMD has a very good work environment. People are allowed to express their ideas and opinions freely. The pressure is limited, and people are promoted based on actual work, not who kisses ass the best
column14: Management at times is disconnected from their employees. The hands on manager is hard to come by. Very few personal relations exist between management and employees.

column13: Company growth opportunities exist, but we have major leadership issues which range from incompetence, to ignorance, and to ego problems.
column14: People don't get rewarded for thier efforts but by whom they know and click with.  Basically at AMD to get ahead, its all about playing the game 150% of the time.  The actual job performance really doesn't matter.

column13: AMD has many good, smart people.  Most people at AMD are energetic, focused, and genuinely strive towards the best interests of the company.
column14: AMD is still growing.  It lacks some of the infrastructure required for a company of it's size to run efficiently.  As with any company, there are still some people and groups that internally behave with a protectionist, zero-sum-game mentality, but they are in the minority.

column13: Company vision and leadership. The most advanced technology in semi-conductor. Strong rewards and ability to have an impact.
column14: Things move fast, but I love the work

column13:
High potential for growth
Solid engineering staff
Decent benefits package
Sabbatical program means time away from work to recharge your batteries
column14: Decision making diffused between too many people - takes too long to make decisions.\r\nTakes too many people to get work done relative to other companies\r\nEngineering concentrates too much on building microprocessor cores, not microprocessor chips

column13: Rewarded well for bright minded individuals who can contribute to AMDs success.
column14: Volatile market, but if your good you have nothing to worry about.

column13: People are innovated, talented and very friendly here. Most importantly, I'm motivated in many ways because we have a clear direction and goal here.
column14: Can't think of any

column13: Being an underdog and the urge to perform better.\r\nLaid back work culture.\r\nhaving some great engineers.
column14:
All time low employee morale.
Getting to know more info from external sites than from the management.
Communication meetings that are not upto the mark.
Always the motto being to catch up with Intel rather than lead the way and think out of the box.

column13: People are friendly, smart, and laid back. Most people arrive sometime before 9am, leave before 5pm. Working from home is an option for most. The work is fun, demanding and sometimes rewarding
column14: Dismal economic standing, limited promotions within, lots of management changes. Lots of good people laid off has meant that a lot of work has been left undone over the last year. Many of these holes have been unfilled, meaning that required stuff just doesn't get done.

column13: Management tries to communicate with employees, work hours are flexible, and I get to work on interesting projects that directly lead to products.
column14: They keep cutting cost, and we're asked to work with minimum resource and amenities.  It's discouraging that we're always being squeezed.

column13: The campus is large and great scenery.  Just a wonderful environment.
column14: Only Re-locating was not efficient for me.

column13: I find the work enjoyable and challenging, and feel like I am appreciated. Still working on reasonably cutting edge technology. Upper leadership seems to be trying their best to stabilize the company and grow it for the future. Reasonably good benefits. Generally a nice place to work in terms of atmosphere.
column14: Life as the underdog can get a bit wearing - only time will tell if the bets taken by leadership will stem the perennial lean times. Some of the cost cutting measures can introduce some annoying issues.

column13: Good work life balance and Great place to work if you want to be a computer architect !!
column14: Hasn't created any profits for past few years!!

column13: Great technology that is starting to bring the company out of the long struggle it has had.
column14: Much like a startup in that they are missing a lot of rigorous processes that one would expect of a company that has been around so long.   They try to run very lean and risk burning out key people.

column13: The people on my team.  Very smart and dedicated.
column14: Financial Uncertainty of the company.  Multiple rounds of layoffs over past year.

column13: The only other x86 company; some very good people to work with. A place to change the  industry with enough focus
column14: lack of resources for projects, misapplied resources, lack of focus, multi-site projects. Need better focused management that realized the need for concentrated focus on the pc market and not chase after niches. goal needs to be to take %'s away from intel.

column13: Good pay.  Good work\u002Flife balance.  Get to do some interesting travel depending on your role.
column14: Hopelessly behind Intel on CPU performance and can't figure out how to make use of their graphics advantage.  Most of the good people I worked with have moved on.  Could use better processes on the marketing side.

column13: AMD is a great place to work - coworkers are friendly and resourceful. The hour is flexible, and working from home is not an issue. Managers tries to accommodate what people want to learn and grow. There are always interesting work.
column14: There are layoff frequently - almost every year, range from 5-15%. Company is not growing and constantly in cost-down mode.

column13: Very dedicated team. Excellent cooperation across the enterprise. A solid combination of long term employees with people who've come from outside. Excellent people in Asia supporting the operations.
column14: This company cannot seem to maintain profitability at all. In my 5 years, it was a roller coaster. The move to tablets caught AMD by surprise and now they are reeling. Can they ever get out of this funk? Salary was great, but bonuses were too rare.

column13: Great work life balance..
column14: Not among highest paying companies

column13: Technical and organizational challenges abound. But that is a result of its downsides.
column14: Immature and incompetent upper management. There are no technical visionaries, neither are there any business and management visionaries. Upper management in one division of the company is bungling through products. Only reason they make any money is because of equally immature competition. The other major division is rudderless, following the leader blindly. Not the healthiest of situations.

column13:
* Great personal life/work life ratio
* Smart teammates
* Good campus
* Your opinions are heard. Directors and below want to hear what you have to say.
column14: * Recent setbacks have lessened morale\r\n* Engineering needs to have more emphasis, and not disregarded by other teams.\r\n* Not all work gets appreciated

column13: Smart, talented and driven group of engineers\r\nGood learning opportunities for younger engineers\r\nWhen times are good, bonuses are good
column14: Long hours, weekend and holiday work is expected\r\nThe middle and upper management are out for themselves and force workers to make up for their poor decisions\r\nTitles and ranking and rating are out of whack in many cases.

column13:
Good people as peers
Base compensation is good as bonusses are infrequent
Austin is a nice place to live
Interesting technlogogies, especially for hardware designers
column14:
Bonusses are infrequent 
Poor execution
Not much training or other support infrastructure
Management is mostly good old boy silos
Lots of management spin about things getting better soon
Very little opportunity for job rotations
Much business/market risk due to the competative environment

column13:
1) Awesome co-workers. 
2) Fun work.
3) Flexible timing including the possibility to work from home pretty regularly.
4) Cheap medical benefits.
column14:
1) Management not transparent.
2) Promotions are very rare.
3) Not easy to move to other groups
4) It seems to be very political at higher up levels.
5) Lots of false promises with regards to promotions and raises.

column13: AMD has some of the smartest and most dedicated people I have ever met working at it.  Innovations and beyond the cutting edge technology can be found everywhere. Plenty of opportunity to move within the company. It is never the same day twice.
column14: Understaffed aggressive plans lead to frustration and burn-out.  Executive direction can be unfocused and often contradictory. Management often lacks the courage to say \"no\".

column13: No lack of interesting work, friendly co-workers,  beautiful campus with onsite Gym
column14: Ever increasing work due to voluntary or involuntary workforce reduction. Not enough compensation or recognition of hard work. You have to be really good in PR to get ahead. Very risky future, at least for 2015.

column13: Cutting edge technology, lots of experienced people to learn from, benefits were great, salary was very competitive. Work culture was very relaxed, no high pressure deadlines on projects. Very extensive IT and compute support. Tool licenses were never an issue (what a delight).
column14: People with lots of experience who are closed to listening to anyone coming from the outside. Very narrow focus on how designs should be implemented. Old design flows that are hardly used by the rest of the industry. Even within the company ATI is miles ahead of AMD in ASIC flows for low power cpus.

column13: - co-workers are fairly good\r\n- there is a degree of openness to sharing knowledge among colleagues\r\n- flexible work time
column14: - felt like there were too many managers and not enough workers\r\n- upper management not in synch with employees\r\n- management do not communicate effectively

column13: There is chances for growth with alot of change.  It you want to build a career, this is a good place to do it.
column14: There are alot of changes and the pressure of the job sometimes is alot.  Not a place for a slacker.

column13: Good technology, especially graphics. Definitely the current APU (single-SoC CPU + GPU + support) leader. Dynamic environment, plenty of opportunity.
column14: Too much churn in project definition and priorities. Need better alignment of cross-organization priorities. Some groups become way over-stretched.

column13: The engineering projects are interesting with lots of technical challenges.   The work environment is also quite good with minimum politics since there are less meetings.
column14: The unstable financial condition of the company is a problem since there have been layoffs in the past few years.\r\nThe company can also provide more training for employees so employees can pick up the most advance technology.

column13: The work is fun and challenging. In the product development field we work to ensure designs can be manufactured and productized reliably and cost effectively.
column14: The company has had many up's and downs. High amounts of middle management which makes product direction and policy difficult at times. At time of writing most engineers are overworked due to company wide attrition.

column13: interesting work\r\nexperienced poeple\r\ngreat place to ramp up and see how things are done
column14:
tough competition from Intel and NVidia
company lost money for years now
promotions/recognitions are slow
very long work cycles leading to burnout

column13: Interesting and challenging work at the forefront of the CPU and GPU markets.  Lots of opportunities to learn about the latest technologies.
column14: Rough economy and poor execution on the CPU side of the business has prevented the company from providing proper compensation and benefits to retain important staff.

column13:
Grossly understaffed, so everyone picks up big chunk of work
People are friendly.
Relaxed culture, although outings have dramatically reduced in last few years.  
Exposed to cutting edge technology.
column14:
Middle management don't take any decisions.
Top heavy
Reviews are unfair.
Money situation always tight...small pie, too many mouths to feed.  Money that trickles down to engineers is pennies on the dollar.

column13: Lots of great engineering staff to work with\r\nWork can be interesting if you can get in the right department
column14:
Salaries are average unless you are in management position.
AMD strives for average benefits.
Management doesn't not really want people who think out of the box and question them - just say yes and be quiet.
Newer management hasn't a clue about what's going on.  I think they are just there to collect their parachutes and move on.

column13: Manager is friendly.  They do not  push
column14: the caffe is not very good

column13: Good location, good networking, friendly people. Very nice people to work with and a lot of cool processes and technologies to work with.
column14: Disorganized teams, understaffed, bad quick and dirty solutions to things, not alot of innovation happening in the team I was working in. Poor relocation services

column13: The company lets you work from home most of the time, which is refreshing. Base salary is good, stocks\u002Fbonus not so much.
column14: No proper communication within the company. AMD needs some 'google groups' infrastructure.\r\nUnstable future. Management doesn't focus on the right projects. Due to working from home, the office can feel empty.

column13: A positive culture that promotes individual growth.
column14: Company growth has been so successful office space is a premium.

column13: There are some very capable technical people but there are just as many doing little and hanging on. Austin is more affordable than CA.
column14: Software development is considered less valuable than hardware. There is a bit of a silo mentality which creates competition between teams that should be working together.

column13: The technology is very cool and the company is small enough that you can make a real difference. The fusion stuff where CPUs and GPUs work closely together is awesome.
column14: The company can't seem to make money. Products are constantly canceled. Schedules constantly shift. Responsibilities and ownership for common stuff is often unclear. Lots of schedule chicken and passing the buck. Decisions often don't get made at all, or at best they are delayed until the last possible moment.

column13: salary is good at austin amd
column14: presure at austin amd at austin amd

column13: People have always been AMD's best resource.\r\nThe environment is casual and encourages personal intiative.\r\nThe company plays an important part in the community.
column14: Management focuses too much on the short-term. People are no longer viewed as the most important resource owned by the company.\r\nNot enough attention is given to career development.

column13: Cutting edge technology, fast moving, underdog against massive competitor, cool toys.  Management is people-focused, compensation is good. I'm a fan of the place I work, and that's relatively rare.
column14: The process can be overbearing for the size company that it is, but it works and management tends to be flexible.

column13: Nice peers and no micromanagement, work and life balance, open discussion and communication, people and my manager are very accessible
column14: Bad decisions from high level managers, too many meetings, politics politics politics! sometimes it makes the working environment intolerable and very inefficient. junior people are underpaid and they are the hard-working guys.

column13: Flexibility of work type. You can shape your career as you want. \r\nManagement will provide the opportunity
column14: Your furture is in your reporting managers hand. He can misuse the performance rating feedback.\r\nNo one in upper management, will question his rating.  There is a repeated misuse of the \"performance rating\" system.

column13: AMD is a good place to learn about complex semiconductor products in all aspects.  There are good opportunities in design, testing, and product definition.
column14: The senior leadership is all about doing what someone else has already done.  Developing new IP, or new products for new areas is not what AMD is about.  If you are interested in any kind of marketing, don't join AMD.

column13: If you want to learn, AMD is the place. You will have enough opportunity and time to learn new things. There is enough opportunities to go around. Work life balance is very good. Design cycles are drawn out over 2-3 years.
column14: Poor revenue and limited financial growth. Poor management unable to turn around the company

column13: Work life balance\r\nCareer growth\r\nFriendly colleagues that want to help you be successful
column14: Some colleagues are not as strong as others which pulls the overall team down.  \r\nCorp processes and approvals can slow us down.

column13: Was able to learn a lot and have many opportunities for career movement.  Pay in the Semiconductor industry is typically very good.
column14: Semiconductor is rough industry.  Company has a bit of a chew you up and spit you out attitude - don't really care about people.

column13: - Friendly co-workers\r\n- Not so stressful as some other companies\r\n- Management flexible with employee requests
column14: - Compensation and benefits mediocre for such a large company\r\n- Still no ESPP\r\n- Career growth is mainly a horizontal thing. If you want to move up, you mostly have to move out.

column13: Nice campus, flexible work hours, some good people left but maybe not for much longer
column14: Company doesn't make money, doesn't pay bonuses and when they do they are small.  No clear corporate direction.

column13: If you are reasonably smart and hardworking (and manage to keep your job through reorgs), fairly good place from work-life balance perspective
column14: * Management tries to exploit limited opportunities in Boston area in chip design, by not compensating people properly.\r\n* Misalignment in leveling across locations (especially management in Boston does not reward employees at same level as other locations)

column13: Work\u002Flife balance strongly encouraged along with continuous learning. AMD can be considered alpha testers with new technology, giving focused employees constant exposure.
column14: don't expect guidance from management for growth beyond the current position; use the work\u002F live balance, down time  and flexibility to develop your own plan of growth, execute it, and give management the option to get on board or out of the way.

column13: A pro for me is most definitely that the people are so very competent here, particularly the excellent engineering staff.
column14: It's a con to be at a place where the senior management is very poor, and the senior management is poor here.

column13: People People People.  The people I work with are fantastic and talented.
column14: Wish there was more TRUE accountability, responsibility and trust between executive management and the people that run the business day in and day out.

column13: There is a good company culture in the balance of work & personal life with a sense of united spirit in competition against AMD's competitors.
column14: On the down side the company has struggled financialy the last couple years of years with a resulting drag on salaries & promotions.

column13: Great Company & good potential for future growth, specially after addition of ATI graphics team to already existing processr team
column14: AMD has still way to go before competing against microprocessor giant like Intel. It will take a few years before it reaches its prime

column13: Challenging work from the technical side of things\r\nGood benefits\r\nBeautiful campus
column14: Incompetent upper management\r\nOnly the best for management, and the least for the technical staff.\r\nManagement refuses to admit when they are wrong, and will sink the company rather than change.

column13: great people to work with. collaborative environment. cutting edge work. flexible work schedule. opportunity to work in areas in uptick. short term prospects good. Also ability to be exposed to various disciplines of work.
column14: bad strategy and unrealistic planning. Poor compensation.  Unstable financial performance. \r\nproffesional growth limited due to growth stagnation at company.

column13: Loved the people I worked with, With shrinking workforce there are always abilities to grow and further career. Some potential always there for a great product,,,
column14: Town halls are the same each time. Product direction really like a gamble, not much R&D so its always like rolling the dice with each product launch as to whether it will be good or not,,,

column13: People, Location, Company Culture, Offices, work-life balance
column14: Salary, no free food, Austin is very hot in the summer

column13: Good work life balance. Have opportunities to work on emerging technologies
column14: Nothing I could think of

column13: Great passion from the working level down.
column14: Management sometimes is uncomfortable with smart engineers.

column13: Work on cutting edge technology, can make significant contribution to the company. Manager have technical skill, and very supportive to team.
column14: Compensation not competitive, Need to revisit the pay strutted. Also may broaden her product line, and invest more on new area

leadership

can work from home

layoffs

column13: You have opportunity to work on projects with broad scope that you can impact the company. Company is growing and they value your effort.
column14: Long hours are pretty common. Upper level management keep overworking the engineers by squeezing many projects one after another. There is no rest.

column13:
Good products.
Sincere desire by employees to be successful.
Compensation is good.
Good benefits.
Management understands the need for a balanced lifestyle.
column14:
Top heavy.  Too many executives and not enough folks doing the work.
Internal communication is poor.
Too much reorganization, departments are siloed.
Not fiscal prudent unless in a financial crisis.

column13: Managers are really flexible in terms of work hours. \"Benefits\" and recognitions can vary greatly depending on the project you are working on. \r\nLots of opportunities to go on business trips which are as good as paid vacation at AMD if you are lucky enough to work on important project.
column14: Criteria and standards for performance and achievement rating is a joke

column13: AMD was the impetus for my career growth and provided fair compensation based on my experience and job description\u002Ftitle, great and well-maintained facilities, nice cafe with plentiful cuisine options
column14: It felt stifling and dreary to be in an environment where annual revenue reports were declining with every passing quarter. Also needs to invest in a higher comp package commensurate with experience

column13: work from home\u002Fflexible hours, friendly down to earth coworkers,  opportunities to travel worldwide,  wearing multiple hats, fast paced environment
column14: work\u002Flife balance - always understaffed,  lack of direction from upper management, sexism rampant within business unit, management created toxic work environment

column13: AMD as a company still has good brand recognition\r\nAMD has successfully renegotiated its licensing terms with its arch rival intel
column14: AMD has too much politicking within its walls and company definies itself against intel which is dangerous\r\nAMD has huge amount of debt and cash on hand position has not improved

column13:
Opportunities to move around within the company. 
Management allows employees to take vacation when they like.
Lots of very talented engineers.
Management communicates very well.
column14: Resource starved and so lot of things that are planned do not get executed.\r\nLack of educational support - it is almost impossible to take classes for career development.

column13: Good working environment, small team and greater say in decision making makes AMD a good place to work for.
column14: AMD has not been doing well since 2007, which results in less pay and paltry bonus or sometimes no bonus.

column13:
* there are many knowledgeable engineers to learn from, nice to work with
* get to expose to wider technical area than some competitors
* typically flexible work schedules
* proud to be one of the very few companies to design everyday and high end CPUs
column14: * not paying well at least for recent years (the company is in bad shape financially)\r\n* medical benefit so so

column13: Lots of very smart people, can have interesting products depending on which sub division you are in
column14: Chaotic, highly political, despite a reasonably flat organization very title driven, if you are not part of one of the  fiefdoms you are not valuable

column13: People are pretty cool. General culture is heavily weighted toward life before work. Pay is decent.
column14: Big disconnect between senior management and everyone else. Most people seem content to run out the clock. Very few shining stars -- most people who are destined for greatness find it elsewhere. Tremendous amount of inside politics.

column13: good team environment. The work culture is very friendly. The management is very pro active and motivating to work. The benefits are also good.
column14: there are no specific cons as such. but to move into a different domain and work is little difficult in this firm.

column13: - Learn lot of cutting edge CPU\u002FGPU knowledge and how to deal with politics.\r\n- Learn and get away unless you are bosom friend of your boss.   You will get bulletproof vest exempt from layoff.
column14:
- Very political and nepotism.  Hiring and promotion only for their dull and unqualified old buddies.  Work hard doesn't mean have chance to get reward or promotion, but reciprocated by layoff. 

- Low level developers are undervalued and overworked.  Managers and old timers are relax, slow, unproductive and WFH. Perfect work-life balance and fat salary for them. Top notch favoritism. Shameless mouth-blabbering wins over dedicated and skilled hard workers.  

- Almost two years turmoil, but it won't stop.  Upper management cuts many x86 projects and treats employee like COST and DIRT, middle management only care about their job aggressively throw their resources under the bus to cover their ass.  Later on, they have to hire engineers back to run projects.  This stupid "AMD routine" never saved cost and defer product launch schedule.

- Now this is a place for mouth-blabbers, smart-talkers and shameless butt-kissers. Not a place for skilled and honest folks to invent exciting products.

column13: A good place to start out in semiconductor industry.
column14: Management lacks judgment in recruiting new talent. Witnessed many technically-challenged recruits brought in to man senior engineering positions, thus breeding discontent among the seasoned but reticent engineers. Compensation does not commensurate with work.

column13: Great technology & extremely smart people working toward a lofty vision. If you want to change the world of technology work here.
column14: Management incompetence, poor employee development. Engineering very detached from the business side of things. Management seems more interested in their next paycheck than taking the company to new levels.

column13: AMD is a good place to work. There are very few walls between departments.  People are generally supportive.. especially once you have that face to face meeting.
column14: Sometime, it is hard to change from doing things the old way.  But generally, people can be convinced.

column13: good balance between life and work. Friendly environment with good people around you. If you are good, you will be respected
column14: compensation can be a bit lower than other places. No other major complaints. Starting to be more flexible with compensation

column13:
Great People
Access to enterprise technology
Opportunity to grow and learn for those who want it.
Challenging problems and issues to solve.
column14: Not all the challenges are technical...\r\nThe pace can change quickly and with muddled direction from management.\r\nSalary not on par with the industry.

column13: The company has many smart people, fosters a culture of meritocracy within the engineering teams, and supports development of employees.
column14: It's always been tough to ride the endless waves of boom and bust cycles in the ever changing computer industry.

column13: Great culture, very helpful peers and sharp managers. Some projects have startup kind of feeling. It's a great place to hone skills and grow.
column14: Unstable roadmaps. Sometimes the work pressure is too high and sometimes it is too low. The upper management could be better organized and can have better vision.

column13: Nice place to work \r\nGood managers

column13: The technical related to CPU is state-of-art .
column14: the benefit is good to me

column14: None that I know of

column13:

- company in permanent financial trouble; don't count on a bonus

column13: There is no good reason to work at AMD (as an engineer)
column14: Staffing is boom and bust - today they hire, tomorrow they lay off.   Line management is engineering throwbacks so tread cautiously to stay on their good side.  Be careful of your co-workers - they will throw you under the bus to save their own skin.  \r\nThe work is all incremental changes to existing stuff.   Not great for skills - the industry will outpace you.

column13: The best reasons to work for AMD are the people and technology.  The group is great.  My team leader is excellent.  My manager is awesome.

column13: - Work life balance\r\n- Cutting edge products

column13: AMD offers it's employees great benefits and the work environment is friendly. I worked at the Southwest Austin location, great location.

column13: Great people to work with
column14: Some coworkers are based overseas

column14: Work\u002Flife is also the problem: everyone hits the door at 5 and nobody is burning the midnight oil making the next big thing.

column13: easy going culture\r\ngood severance package

column13: AMD still has some great people to work with.
column14: Top level direction has not succeeded in stablizing the decline. Significant layoffs have increased the workload for survivors. The current marketplace problems are not related to the economy at large - the products are uncompetitive.

column13: Great talented people\u002Fengineers\r\nCompetative Pay and benefits\r\nBeautiful Go Green Campus located in the Hill Country
column14: Business is suffering greatly and layoffs are occuring on an annual basis if not more often.

column13: Lots of smart, driven people. Lots of room to use new tech and solve problems as you see fit, not much micro managing.

column13: Potentially good work\u002Flife balance if you don't have too many conference calls in off hours.\r\nChallenging projects
column14: Potentially (very) bad work\u002Flife balance because projects are often executed at too many sites. A lot of off-hours conference calls and work.\r\nCustomer satisfaction is not a high priority at AMD. Continuing financial challenges make people to focus on internal matters rather than customers.\r\nToo frequent changes in product roadmap and plan.

column13: - Great people to work with\r\n- Good experience which will help you in future\r\n- Flexible work schedule
column14: - Hard work and commitment means nothing when it comes to layoffs, which is common here at AMD\r\n- Product delays are common which could lead to it being scrapped.. so when the ship sinks, make sure you are not on board

column13: Cutting edge technology.\r\nLots of talented engineers
column14: Chaos in direction and management. No clear direction. Lots of politics at management level.\r\nNot enough opportunities to grow.

column13: There is a paycheck.  You get a few benefits.  Hours are long but sometimes flexible.   Lots of good people still work there.
column14: Numerous.  Benefits are poor.  Health insurance is very expensive relative to other companies. You are not insured while traveling on company business.

column13: Leadership, technology stack, current direction the company is heading, and their ability to deliver high quality technology that is far superior than competitors.
column14: Fast growing which can make it difficult to get things done. Processes need to be updated for fast changing technology landscape.

column13: Great people, supportive environment. Bleeding edge technology.
column14: Management is a bit too hardware focused when there is a lot of software needed to take advantage of the hardware.

column13: There are a lot of smart engineers working at AMD that, given the proper chance, can do great things with limited resources.  The work environment is fairly relaxed and flexible.
column14: Incompetent executives,  lack of corporate direction, canceled important projects, removal of benefits, poor health plan (UHC), no bonuses or pay raises.

column13: Great place to learn. You are one of the few that really understands how to build complex chips.
column14: It is like working for the Government. The decisions are slow.

column13: 1) The people - engineers (hardware, software and debug) were fantastic people.  Lower management as well were all hard working and conscientious.  I would gladly call everyone I worked with my friend.\r\n2) Work life balance - Other than bringup\u002Flaunch times, plenty of leeway was given to do the things that we all want to do: go to school with kids, eat dinner at home with family, go the the gym, etc.\r\n3) Doing what you want - I was firm enough with my manager that when I said I was going to do something, I meant it.  So, when I wanted to learn something new, I was able to go do it.
column14: 1) Squeaky wheel syndrome - I was squeaky, so I got more grease than those around me, but they don't give you ANYTHING that you don't demand.  They really should reward people for their effort, not for their complaining.\r\n2) Management sucks - I was there for 7 or 8 rounds of layoffs and I kept watching the talent walk out the door while the managers and PMs filled their ranks with \"architects\" and fellows.

column13: Cutting Edge Work\r\nTons of opportunity for career advancement unfortunately caused by people leaving\r\nSmart Coworkers
column14:
Constant Turmoil and Flux
Under staffing meant long hours 
Business Climate meant little pay advancement
Pockets of low morale permeated the company

column13: good quality of people and work, time flexibility at work is the best thing  they offer. Company has head office in california but now a days every decision is taken in Austin
column14: company not making profit as the projects they are working are not good. they should motivate employees and should accept the new innovative ideas.

column13: Good pay and benefits, great work culture, decent work\u002Flife balance
column14: Yearly layoffs, consistent sub-par financial performance, future financial health is uncertain, it is not apparent that meaningful strategy corrections have been made to change the present course

column13: Work-life balance.  Walk my dog every day at lunch.  Can afford to live near the office.  Working on products anyone can buy is pretty cool.
column14: Schedules are always set unrealistically aggressive and lessons are seldom learned.  Hate describing the company on the street to people as Intel's competitor.

column13: Great place to think outside the box. Good company culture and you feel proud of your work. Teammates really work with you towards common goal.
column14: Many groups are understaffed requiring longer hours than other companies. Pay is also less competitive vs. similar companies.

column13: Good work-life balance.  Seasoned Engineers with extensive experience in x86 designs.
column14: Compensation does not match with the market. It used to be a engineering powerhouse but no more. Lot of good engineers have left and leaving on a daily basis.

column13:
At AMD, you will likely benefit from:
-Work/life balanace
-Advancement opportunities
-Annual raises (depending on performance)
-Sabbatical (after 7 years)
-Name recognition good for future job opportunities
column14:
-Pay tends to be slightly below average
-Benefits are decent, but not oustanding
-The underdog syndrome (vs. Intel)
-Telecommuting policy depends on department or individual manager

column13: Large semiconductor industry player, access to whole platform experience
column14: Some nepotism, frequent changes in long term strategy, overall lack of strong competent leadership. Great fundamentals (people, technology, resources) but continued poor leadership makes AMD a tough place to recommend.

column13: The people are great. A very family friendly company. The office always has a good feel to it. It is very rare to run into anyone that is not nice.
column14: Wish the company had a solid direction in the industry, instead of being happy with being number 2. This mentality goes all the way down too.

column13: Company has great technology and people.  They are the only company that has both x86 and high end graphics.
column14: Very confused on their product roadmaps.  We have now gone full circle back to the company strategy that the CEO in 2010 was let go for.  They are understaffed to be effective in getting products to the market and financially in a very difficult position.

column13: great graphics technology, good work-life balance most of the time, some good research opportunities, relaxed work ethic, nice coworkers, not too much local politics

column13: Excellent engineer staff and cooperative environment
column14: Unhealthy business, bad bonuses as a result. No job stability. Super efforts are the expectation and are undervalued.

column13: Pretty good parental leave program, lots of social events and food, decent benefits

column13: Good company and with many technical colleagues, can learn lots of interesting things.

column14: Long working hours. Toxic work environment. Manager often make racist\u002Fcontroversial remarks(no idea how she can get away with this for so long but no one actually does anything about it since she is  “capable” in her job), very gossipy, make nasty remarks about others as though the people around can’t hear. Not a conducive work environment, have to be in office or you are frowned upon(even if you have given valid reasons). It can also get quite noisy as there are many unproductive chatting irrelevant to work. When given the feedback to manager, I was told that it is something I have to accept and learn, rather than actually making the work a better place to work in. Definitely not the type of work environment I would want. Company also started to track the number of times employees actually come into the office in order to ensure you are utilising your seat\u002Ftable. So much effort being put into this sort of matters - is it necessary to track? Typical toxic corporate environment - and I was told to accept that’s how it is rather than the manager trying to change her management style. Being micromanaged but insisted that they are not micromanaging, not open minded and insist on hearing things only the way they want.

column13: Work and projects are good. The way work is managed is dependent on the manager, but if you don't like, you can switch to another team. Most teams have politics free work environment. Standard protocol post covid is - compulsory work from office for minimum of 3 days to retain your desk \u002F monitors \u002F workstation setup, else with prior managers approval, you can work from home permanently with office provided laptop and you'll have to invest in ergonomic kit (office desk, monitor, office chair, etc.) at your personal expense.

column14: Its been a year I am with AMD. Below are some of the Cons which might help you while choosing your next destination. 1. There is no work-life balance at all. In the motive of beating every competitor out there, AMD is actually killing its employees. Our manager clearly says, there is no work life balance here, there is no option but to work for more than 10-12 hours to complete the work. But in reality, you end up working for 15-16 hours. 2. There is status meeting almost every other day. Tracking is done to very minute level 3. Micromanagement is prevalent 4. They have releases almost every month but time given is so short that one cannot deep dive to its fullest as task needs to be completed soon 5. Their appraisal cycle is worst of anything. Their appraisal period is from Jan to Dec, but the hike is effective from July next year. 6. Due to this, many employees in our team and others are speculating to leave once situation outside settles 7. Because there was uncertainty in market, AMD CEO deducted 20% of yearly bonus from every employee. And few days later, she was entitles a bonus of ~1 Million USD. Hypocrisy. 8. The reason AMD was in top 100 best companies to work is because their share price has increased dramatically and this has benefitted employees. 9. This is the company which doesn't give basic facility like internet bill compensation, office cabs or even proper food in their pantry, though they are making money because of the hardwork of employees.

column14:
AMD India (Bangalore) is the worst place to work. The management is pathetic. They don't need engineers, they need robots that work day and night and simply follow the instructions. Micromanagement is at the core of the team. Managers and Directors are dictators here. Engineers are slaves to them. You won't find more arrogant and rude director and manager in the industry. You need to follow each and every word they say. They are always right. 

Nobody is going to help you. If you join AMD you are on your own. But everyone will ask for status updates day and night.

Instead of actual work, most of the focus is on meetings. You will spend half of your working hours in meetings and giving status. Therefore making it obvious that you need to spend extra hours to complete the actual work.

There are lot of VLSI companies having much better work culture than AMD. Join them and save your career.

Once you join AMD, there won't be any increments and bonuses given to you for more than a year.

Save your personal life and your career. Stay away from AMD.

column13: There are many benefits afforded to the employees. It goes beyond the standard medical\u002Fdental benefits. There are Intern\u002FStudent committees that organize events (including gaming) for the students that have joined, there is a gym available to all employees (Markham campus), team building events, BBQ, etc.\r\n\r\nAMD is also active in community events such as tree planting, park cleanup, donations to charities, etc.
column14: Pre-COVID, the Markham campus had issues with the quantity of available parking spaces especially during the winter where everyone tries to park in the underground parking.\r\n\r\nDepending on the team you are on, late nights and weekend work may be required more often than expected.

column13:
1. ESPP is nice.
2. Vacation days increase from 15 days to up to 25 days based on service time.
3. Your experience depends on the team you end up on. Stay away from post silicon teams in general if you value work-life balance.
4. Free parking on site. Lots of good restaurants near the office.
column14:
1. Overtime is expected and is considered normal (60+ hours per week). Get prepared to give up most of your evenings, weekends and holidays. Note that this does not mean your efforts will be appreciated or that you will advance in your career faster. Some senior employees even work through vacation days.
2. Management does not care about employees. Constantly looking to make employees work through weekends, christmas break etc. with no additional pay or days back in lieu. Middle management blames senior management by saying these are requests cascaded from the top. 
3. Pay is the lowest in the industry. Competition (Intel/NVIDIA) pays significantly higher. For example, the base salary of a new grad at Intel is more than a senior engineer at AMD. 
4. Look out for "recharge days" through out the year. These recharge days come directly out of your vacation days. Sometimes a recharge day might fall on a friday which you take off and burn a vacation day, and then you might be expected to come in on the saturday to work. You do not get any additional pay or a day off in lieu for coming on a saturday. 
5. You'll notice that a lot of junior employees/new grads have lead positions. This is management trying to squeeze as much juice as possible while paying the lowest possible salaries.
6. Some teams can be cliquey. Some managers fraternize with some direct reports ( hanging out constantly outside of work ) which is completely unprofessional and leads to favouritism. If you're not part of this inner circle, you get passed over for promotions or higher raises. 
7. Female CEO but women face constant sexism. Women coming back from maternity leave lose their progress in advancing to the next level. Women taking their full maternity leave entitlement get shamed/talked about behind their back (as if maternity leave is a vacation). In the last women's day event held by the company, the guest speakers included caucasian male executives which many women raised as distasteful.
8. High turnover of experienced employees over the past year.
