column13:
- Cfo and director are chill.
- Company doesn't enforce dress code.  Can come to work in sandals, running shoes, leggings, Tshirts, tanktops, shorts, miniskirts, and jeans anyday of week.  it feels great i can wear whatevr i want
- No credentials required.  Thought I needd an accountng designation or university degree, but don’t need to know accounting knowledge and still do financial rporting, budgeting, and forecasting.  Don't even need to know Excel to do finncial reporting, bdgeting, and forecasting.  Don't even need know math to do financial reportng, busdgeting, and forcasting.  Great they hired me!
- Always lots of fod, snack, treats in building
- teammates are cool and hellpful.  Feels like a family.  Socials are enjoyable. Company functions outside work are fun.
column14:
- Managers below CFO and Director are bullies.  They sit together in the corner and act childish and make fun of their employees.  
- Too lazy to do thir own wrk.  
- Never arund to provide ledership.  Always taking 2 hour lunches - gone 11:50, they come bck 1:30 (not just friday) and leave at 4 when they come in at 9.
- Don't know how to train people.   
- Managers don't know how to act professional.
- Always ask very personal questions and won't leave you alone until you answer to their liking, then will make fun of you and embarass you 
- Campany has poor health and dental bnefits
- Very loud working envrinonemnt.  Workers are allowed to play music and not use headphones.
- Managers clearly play favorites.  Pick on and bully quiet ones constantly, and joke with others.  Have not heard of anyone saying they are good managers, they are just there to approve vacation time, or be 17th floor security guards. If there are any "positive" posts here about accoutning department after this one, it is fake.
- Probably the worst work envirnment in terms of managers, training, professionalism, and job growth compared to other places i've worked.  the problem is the managers have been thre too long so don't know what the real world is like any more.  What they think is professional or how a company should act, is not normal because they are in a bubble.
- Do not work in CDW-Canada finance dpeartment if you have a university degree (or even a high school diploma).  Your better off working somewhere else.  You will get better training and more challenge somewhere else, and will probably have more professional managers and not be bullied.
- Would not recommend CDW-Canada finance department to build your career

column14:
1. It's an old white boys club. I say that as a white individual. It sucks that's how MFN rolls. They say they value diversity but they don't. They will have a token diverse person in an exec role but they're there to be a face, not make any changes or impact. 
2.  They pay really well but that hurts when you leave. 
3.  They layoff the good people and keep the undereducated white males. Why? See #1 above.
4.  They don't want you if you are female and over 40. Think I'm lying? See the number of females 40+ who got hit in the January "reorganization." 
5.  HR is a joke. Talent acquisition couldn't find their rear ends with both hands and a map. So many excuses on why they didn't do their jobs. 
6.  MFN said the HealthNet employees needed to learn the Centene way and the Centene way would prevail. He lied. 
7.  They never entertained the idea of working from home. At all. Even a 25% WFH option would cut costs and improve morale.

column13: Virtual work and you get to work with agents by taking them out to meals and take them golfing on the company. Most of the time you don’t have to do a lot as long as you have good relationships with agents. Super flexible on personal time and allows people to take dogs on walks during conferences calls. Since you work from home it’s great since its acceptable to work 4 or 5 hours in a day.
column14: If you care enough…the customer service is terrible sine you can submit the same problem over and over and it never gets solved. I have learned to let the agents do their own customer service so that when the issues don’t get resolved, I don’t look bad as though I can’t resolve the issue. The pay isn’t great either since we never meet goal. As long as you’re fine with the base and just do t care to much about helping agents or doing well in Medicare sales, WellCare is the place for you. The place is very siloed which is great way to not get anything accomplished but can be frustrating if you actually try to make improvements to the business.

column13: -biggest pro, virtually everyone is full-time and permanently remote. Have only been to offices for voluntary all-hands type events. no signs of RTO -moderate flexibility on daily hours as remote employees are all over US time zones -Standard big-corporate pto\u002Finsurance\u002F401k\u002Fetc -Have seen enough employees move positions\u002Forgs to say mobility is a real option for many people
column14: -typical 'do more with less' attitude, understaffing and overworking is common -it's easy for bad performance to go unnoticed in a big org like this. incompetence\u002Fdishonesty\u002Fblame-shifting is rampant across orgs. -pay is at lower end of industry standard, i've never seen the bonus that was talked about at my onboarding -DEI is talked up heavily during townhalls and such, but is not practiced in reality -the company is just predatory and slimy overall. Business practices are heartless and greedy like you would expect from a mega-corp. it is not healthcare, it is a money-making-scheme that uses insurance premiums as a vehicle. c-suite is desperate to monopolize medicare\u002Fmedicaid for the meal ticket and will go to bizarre lengths to weasel their way into more territories. they happily throw whole programs under the bus if it raises the share price.

column13: Flexible work schedule…and nothing else.
column14: -IT Managers are ill-placed, useless and have nothing to do except micromanage and operate at the team level. -IT Individual Contributor receive zero support from leadership. -C-Suite Leadership is only concerned with their salaries and bonuses. -Mangers shift in and out of teams due to reoccurring reorgs. -Employees have had 5-8 managers over the course of a few years. -Managers are not qualified to properly evaluate their employees because the reoccurring reorg’s do not allow for them to get to know the employees -Visa sponsored employees are afraid to speak up because they are led by fear. -IT employees are overwhelmed and over-worked. -Promotions only happen at the manager and above level. -Individual Contributor roles are not respected my management.

column13: Work-life balance is a priority in my department and my leadership is amazing. The workload is high at times but the challenge is manageable and I am fully supported each day. Career development is strongly encouraged and Centene puts in place steps to ensure growth.
column14: Communication and sharing of information between departments is lacking. This lack is due to, in part, because we are such a large company.

column14: Executive leadership lacking in being visible and providing input. Many of the leaders above team managers were detached from reality and wasted time on department calls. Leadership lacks technical expertise, meaning they lack direction and valuable input on important infrastructure projects which are integral to many actuarial functions. Difficult to move up or have an real career plan even if you are a top performer, because senior\u002Fexecutive leadership doesn't seem to know how to foster talent.

column13: Everyone was seemingly nice when I was hired. But that quickly faded.
column14: From the get go my Supervisor failed to order correct equipment or provide adequate training and even in my training I was taught to skip work because the trainer didn’t know how to train. Then after that it was constant write ups and gaslighting as to there was something wrong with me and not the environment of deception they had created where everyone skips the work that is time consuming and those that are honest are treated as liars for being honest. I would not recommend working for Centene. They are not ethical. All they care about are numbers and being fake and not the actual simplistic job that becomes complex because it’s a culture based on deception and gaslighting.

column13: Great benefits and opportunities offered.
column14: Very little pay for position with a lot of responsibilities

column13: IT, having been my 2nd career path, has been a fantastic ride so far. After almost a dozen years at smaller, Managed Service Providers learning a broad base of skills I landed at Centene. I have thoroughly enjoyed the experience and the career advancement opportunities that have been provided to me. I also have enjoyed the educational support from the company around higher levels of certifications (CISSP) that was provided to me and has given me a much better outlook on the greater enterprise as a whole.
column14: The only downside I have really had to deal with is the sheer size of the enterprise and the red tape that goes along with it. We are also a Federal services provider which adds many more layers of red tape. But this is also what most Fortune 100 companies experience...bureaucracy at scale.

column13: Good base pay, reasonable sales quotas. Leaders are not micromanaging. Being able to work from home for a real salary is a huge advantage. The commute is literally into the office, a relaxing lunch and continue the day. Management are mostly millennials which is both good and bad.
column14: Management is mostly younger people. Not all bad but it can be a bit \"rah rah rah!!!\" by celebrating every advancement with a never ending email chain of \" \"congratulations\" while you are trying to concentrate with a member. It is very meeting heavy, I think we are all able to learn from reading the PowerPoint without someone reading it to me. Meetings at least once a day to cover material that could easily be communicated in an email. These are all very minimal cons, overall it is a great company to work with. I enjoy offering quality health care options to Medicare recipients and helping them know how to use their plan to get the most from it,

column13: Focused on member and provider, great coworkers, company is focused on diversity, equity and inclusion.
column14: Complex systems do not talk to each other.

column13: I learned more here about how to do things the right way than anywhere else in my career of 15 years in health care tech. The people are awesome, the core hours were reasonable, the sense of doing something that matters and that raises the bar was always present.
column14: At times of growth, newer managers could use a little more onboarding into the role with soft skills and gauging how to conduct fair assessments.

column13: 100% remote, easy to move to a new position.

column13: Centene is a great company to work with. They value and respect people. Perks are good. Overall five star.
column14: I don’t know of any cons

column13: Employee engagement, opportunities to get involved, volunteer, CEO transparency, bias toward continuous improvement

column13: -Flexible schedules -Paid holidays including a floater to accommodate cultural differences -Compensation overall is okay -No meeting black out days to give focus days to get things done -CEO Sarah London is extremely smart, progressive, forward thinking leader -Potential of 14 week paid maternity leave -Earned time -Front loaded sick time
column14: -Lots of meetings, a lot only have a small part that applies to your specific role -Compensation ranges by letter but there’s no guarantee to make the range associated with the letter range. -Low balling for salaries is very much so happening -Top heavy bonus structure- recently ripped away bonuses from lower paid employees and gave increased bonuses to higher paid employees -Confusing bonus structure- little to no knowledge of what and when bonuses are or might come - Compartmentalized departments “not my job” and don’t always see the big picture of what their piece is - unrealistic goals- not adjusted down when it’s too high, but adjusted to more if you’re doing well and meet the goal ahead of time

column13: This is a nice place to work if you're in need of getting back on your feet. I currently work from home and most of my day is pretty chill. Centene has helped me tremendously with extensive training and opportunities to learn more about the job without being overly stressful.
column14: The pay isn't great and although you are in constant messaging communication with your team throughout the day, you technically work by yourself.

column13: Pay Benefits Flexibility Opportunity for growth

column13: It was wonderful for 3 years. I love the team I was on, support, respect, team work, etc.
column14: Several of us were moved to a different team that was not well managed. Communication was horrible, lack of team work, no information to support us in the changes, created lack of trust in the company and each other, isolation and lack of interest in my job. Audits were fine. Until urgency to get work done due to upper management not knowing from one day to the next what they are doing and now we have a performance problem. Very disappointing and very frustrating. I feel set up to fail when I was excelling in a position prior. I feel the upper management does not have any idea what they are doing and they spend a lot of wasted time shuffling and trying to justify their jobs. I am very disappointed. I had pride in my job and where I worked. I have a lot of hard feelings about what has taken place.

column13: I work remotely from home. The benefits, time off, pay and work environment are awesome. Literally 15K more than I was making in the hospital after 20 years. Centene is the first company to actually believe in \"work-life balance\". Orientation is extensive and they send you all of the equipment you need. Great company doing needed work to help the community.
column14: Orientation is an \"informational download\". Your brain will be fried after that month. You just have to get through it and then you will love your job. Job listings can be vague. You may not know exactly what you are applying for. The recruiters are only allowed to put a small blurb in about the job. Just get into this company, you will not be sorry.

column13: I enjoy the people and the work. The benefits are good, pay is as expected, PTO time is fair, and you can work from home or the office.
column14: It's a big company. I've always liked working for a large company rather than a small one since the benefits are usually better but I wonder if it isn't TOO big. We've been waiting months and months for something that was promised at the beginning of the year. Why? I need help and training with some software but the team that supports that software emailed me a pamphlet I got off the internet. That's not training! There are a lot of teams and it's hard to find the help I need. Overall, I'm satisfied with the work I'm doing but it could be better.

Money spent on naming sports arenas, and nascar races instead of making sure employees are taken care of and appreciated. IT issues for some departments are pushed back sometimes for years without being solved.

column14: Abusive work environment. Trainer called my computer 5 times while I was working. Then emailed my manager who scheduled a 1:1 and threatened to Write me up because I wanted to complete my work the trainer lied and said I was behind on, but finished 3 days earlier. The manager didn’t even fact check. They gave me a iPhone, chromebook and laptop then proceeded to try and smack me around. I was constantly accused of being behind on work I was done with lol. I was only there a month because my manager felt she could schedule an unlimited amount of meetings with me too threaten and harass me. They are actually a lawsuit waiting to happen. I finished modules whos completion is computer generated and they put them back on and tried to make me do them again as a bullying tactic. There is nothing to this company but narcissism and abusive behavior there is no job. They had nothing because I didn’t allow them to emotionally abuse me so they fired me. I kept asking WHAT IS THE JOB? Because there was none lol just be available to be falsely accused and emotionally abused from 8-5. No thank you

column13: Centene is a great place to work. The health insurance domain is endlessly complex and interesting, and Centene does a good job of tying the work back to the goal of helping people (while also making billions of dollars). The culture is very supportive of parents, neurodiversity, cultural diversity, racial diversity, age diversity, gender diversity and diversity of perspective. Coworkers are generally friendly, and there is a sense of team and community. Work-life balance is great. I do not receive any email or messages after hours or on the weekends. Work is done during the work day (though the downside to that is in the \"cons\" section).
column14: There are many meetings at Centene. Some of the meetings are poorly planned, poorly prepped, poorly facilitated, and poorly followed-up. Some of them are purely procedural and unnecessary. Talented meeting facilitators are very valuable to the company. Recordings of meeting is prohibited except in rare exceptions, and note-taking is not common. That means the business is largely run verbally and synchronously. If you missed a meeting you'll need another meeting with someone who was at that meeting to tell you what happened in the meeting. That is inefficient. It also doesn't accommodate time zones very well, if everyone needs to work synchronously. If you live in the Eastern or Central time zones of the US you will be most comfortable. If you live in the Pacific Time Zone you might find that working Central hours is most effective.

column13: Flexible, PTO, good company culture
column14: lacking career development, little contact with co-workers (wfh)

column13: I have had an excellent experience advancing my career here. I worked my way up from a Member Services Rep and landed in an awesome department with an amazing Director who supports my advancement. I have many opportunities to learn a wide range of skills.
column14: There is always a chance that you may get a not-so-great boss, in which case your experience could be vastly different than mine. I have known people in other departments who have had much worse experiences. Additionally, some of the smaller, local branches are completely different than working in the corporate office.

column13: Ramone and Samantha are a management dream team. I've always felt an important role of bosses is to shield their employees from others that would create stress and hinder performance and these two are the only ones I've experienced that do that. These 2 unicorns also get their hands dirty and learn the work we do instead of acting as if it's beneath them. Makes me feel like we're all in this together. I am given autonomy and support in my role and am never micromanaged. The work is challenging and interesting and I'm never bored. My teammates are great and we (and other department staff) collaborate often via Zoom or Teams so working from home gives me all the benefits of not commuting on Chicago's dicey public transportation (my nephew had to exit the train last week and have my sister pick him up when 4 thugs were harassing him) while sharing and receiving knowledge with others. I really don't think I could ever go back to working in an office after this excellent experience. The pay and benefits are great and I love that we get 2 days off Thanksgiving, Christmas & New Years. We also get 8 hours paid time off Community Impact Time to volunteer for charities of our choice. The culture is diverse, inclusive and progressive in ways most corporations are not. I was floored when the CEO Sarah London stated her interest and intention to not indulge in luxuries people in her role often indulge in. This makes me feel she cares much more about making things right for the member and provider instead of money and prestige. It's nice working for a company than aligns with my values of altruism, hard work and a drive toward excellences without blaming and shaming and other toxic behaviors I've found at other companies. I've worked at places that only care about metrics and AR\u002Fmoney which burns the members as a result of shoddy work. This company lets me take the time to do excellent work which helps members\u002Fproviders and gives me a sense of satisfaction. I've always wanted a job working from home where people leave me alone and let me focus on my work while my bosses eliminate barriers and I have finally found it.
column14: Nothing specific to this company, but Healthcare Revenue Cycle work is a LOT, regardless if you're working on the provider side or the payer side. There is a never-ending amount of work to do and it can be overwhelming. You will never finish and the best one can hope for is finding a realistic stopping point and try to prioritize your important tasks while not letting other work fall through the cracks. All managers are not as great as mine from what I hear. Like all corporate jobs, it's important not to burn yourself out and prioritize work\u002Flife balance. Also like other jobs it can be frustrating that departments don't work together more seamlessly and as a detail-oriented employee that owns their work it's hard to understand why other departments don't self-audit more when I find issues and have to request they fix their mistakes.

column13: Good benefits, can work remote
column14: Management, they can have Favoritism

column13: If you know what you are doing you will do well (but you will still be stressed.) You learn a lot in this position especially if you have industry experience. The benefits are above average, work\u002Flife balance are possible if you communicate, if you have helpful leadership you will be fine. You have the option to work from home or from the office. All in all, I recommend Centene and this position.
column14: If you know what you are doing you will do well but you will still be stressed. Some Leads and Supervisors are not as helpful as they should be. If you cannot handle overtime this position is not for you. This is not for the weak or inexperienced. Time management, patience, and communication are key.

Did nothing, and just had them work with us instead but for 5x the pay... People are very untrustworthy and the company will act shady.

Every email feels like it has 400 recipients too many, and it only takes one disagreement to derail anything if you aren't a VP. Frustrating if you're ambitious, but it's a great place to get a paycheck in the meantime.

column14: Everything aside from my pay was a nightmare most of the time. Now, I am no saint. This company is the epitome of why America is failing and is on national hospice entering 2023. Centene is a wolf masquerading as a caring shepherd for all: employees, shareholders, and least of all= those poor folks who have Centene in charge of their Medicaid\u002FMedicare. To work here= suspend your own soul and prepare to deny others healthcare they need to please your boss (make monthly supervision go better). Who cares about 1...or even 10... enrollee(s) or beneficiaries of a healthpolicy? Nobody, except for Centene and how to squeeze every ounce of profit from that poor American neighbor. When some generation wakes up in America and makes PUBLIC all things people should NOT be motivated to profit off of (i.e. healthcare; prisons)? The way we look back in horror at slavery and working conditions in 1800s\u002Fearly 1900s? That moral horror is EXACTLY how anyone with a conscience will view American healthcare\u002Fprisons from 1945-> present. Centene allows you to profit off the ME train until it consumes you.

column14: Lack of Management Training Lack of Agent Training While I was working with Centene as a supervisor, our agents were not properly trained on the systems. Management did not get trained on systems so we were unable to assist our agents and even our supervisors barely knew the systems themselves. Centene is mostly run by people in Bonifacio and they do not teach anything. They expect the agents to receive a 95% or higher on QA scores but they do not get trained and then us managers have to reprimand them or terminate them,

column13: The people, the resources, and the culture. The people in my org are awesome, and we all work to push the company's security in the right direction. Most everyone is incredibly technical, even amongst management. There are enough financial resources in order to tool our team with the technology we need to succeed. Nobody shies away from a challenge, and everyone has a fairly shared vision for the future and what we all need to do to get there.
column14: Centene isn't a _super_ well-known company, and so there isn't exactly a ton of talent flocking to join up. While we have financial resources for the tools we need, we don't have the people to man all of them as well as we should. Though, maybe you can fix that! The other con is that... it's a big company, and so there is a lot of red tape on actually getting changes through. Everyone is generally on board with the changes, it just has to be run past legal, architecture, risk, business continuity, and their brother before it can be made a reality. Which is understandable, we don't want to bring everything to a screeching halt... it just can be frustrating at times.

column13: Mgmt listens to feedback from employees and makes visible changes to operations and policies based on employee engagement surveys and break out groups in town hall meetings, etc.\r\nWages market increases and working from home have made them VERY competitive within the industry.\r\nLOTS of growth potential in a Fortune 50 company that is less than 40 years old. The sky is the limit for \"go-getter\" types.
column14: Was a bit slow to meet demand for work from home permanence when market competitors made the move sooner, but eventually caught up.\r\nMultiple acquisitions recently and a CEO change for first time in 25 years can always mean some growing pains.\r\nSystems and processes are still catching up to the more established companies; lots of opportunities to remove redundancies, etc.

column13: It's stable work, they seem to really understand or want to serve best the Medicaid population they serve with health plans.\r\nI'd gladly say the ideology of the workplace is progressive and minded towards doing well to those less fortunate.\r\nIf you are interested in furthering your education in Healthcare and related fields they will assist with covering part of the funding needed.
column14:
Cold Calling--feels like there is a lack of options with being productive; either take the flurry of incoming or do the churn of outreach to fulfill requirements set forth. 
Not a lot of room to grow into new roles or duties when many staff members get established and the hierarchies get established. 
Clinical roles are coveted by management to hire. It seems like the non-clinical staff stay around for support roles but when the clinicians depart it's a scrambling feeling to where the non-clinicians are asked to fill the void.
At times I wanted to do further my education further but due to the way their programming works, you'd need to stay with the company for a specified period of time afterwards.

column13: Competitive pay, 6% 401k match, Stock purchase plan at 5% discount, pretty good medical\u002Fdental, fully remote, flexible schedules.

column13: I rarely make company reviews, and when I do, I 100% mean it. Centene\u002FAcariaHealth is by far the BEST COMPANY I've ever worked with. People are not treated as just mere numbers, but humans with real life outside their jobs. It is very difficult to find a company that is competitive and at the same time, caring for their employees and their patients\u002Fclients as well. And I can tell you with confirdence that Centene is one of them. *Possibility of working from home (or Hybrid depending on project involvement) *Competitive Salary *Best leadership *Work-life balance at its finest

column13: Flexible start time. Mature, supportive management and teammates with no catty behaviors or drama. No games being played with metrics that cannot be met unless you're working around the clock-very realistic and fair. Working from home. Great benefits and paid holidays. Challenging work with plenty of opportunities to mix it up by helping people in other departments. All I've ever wanted in this field is for someone to let me sleep in and leave me alone while I work like the Virgo that I am. It's great to be trusted and not micromanaged. Love the new Centene CEO Sarah London she is very smart and progressive and the Meridian CEO Sherry Husa is one of the coolest women on the planet.
column14: I mean, there's a reason it's called work because there is a lot to do and it's not always fun. I'm grateful for the really bad experiences I had at my last 2 corporate jobs (first one had bad mgt, second had toxic coworkers with mgt not taking action for a healthier atmosphere) so I can recognize what a healthy job environment looks like. While I love not being micromanaged, it was difficult when I was low on the learning curve and having to reach out to others and figure stuff out myself while constantly reminding myself that my best is enough. It's a con because that process was stressful but like all challenges met, it turned into a pro when I hung in long enough to get a solid foundation of knowledge and experience. This field can be stressful and you will never learn it all, but with supportive management it is a much better environment to deal with it here than my other jobs.

column14:
*Toxic Wellcare leadership driving the sale of benefits without properly ensuring we can implement them, or the vendors can support them 

*Senior leadership frequently berates/ shames those who ask questions, making it very hard to learn// silencing a lot of previously vocal contributors 

*Toxic leadership using negative reinforcement/ driving productivity through shame and saying things like "you have no future here" when things are not done as that leader would do them 

*Discouraged from flagging issues or potential issues, and punished when pursuing solutions on your own by being told it's "above your pay-grade" and to "stop brining up problems"

*Homogenous environment that alienates diversity of thought and actively suppresses the careers of those who speak out 

*Gaslighting and micro-managing by senior leadership

*Expected to work through weekends and holidays without being asked/ told; told you're a failure if you don't

column14: Management is an absolute joke. No one knows what is going on. You can never get a straight answer about a question\u002Fissue you have. They were very wishy-washy about returning to the office vs staying home and I know they lost numerous employees because of this. \r\nConstant \"process changes\" which make metrics\u002Fcompliance impossible to achieve. They knew the Youth Care department was falling behind on completing assessments for months and now EVERY department is required to help complete them to avoid a sanction in 3 weeks. If we help them we fall behind on our own work and it is making this a very hostile working environment with such low morale.

column13: Expect to work hard, but the work is effective so you feel good about doing a good job, maintaining a standard of excellence. There are good, hardworking people everywhere, Centene is no exception. Some lazy bots too, but the pace at Centene eventually filters them out, so it is likely your coworkers are busting their butt like you are. The company has a lot of good tools, platforms, programs, for employee development. They could be truly effective moving hard workers up the ladder... however, certain key points that would better serve to keep talent satisfied and retained ( benefits, schedule flexibility, metric shadiness for performance evals, work life balance) would cause these programs to be more effective and allow the employee as a whole person flourish into their full potential.
column14: Very poor work\u002F life balance. Employees, and even management, can feel anonymous even though a huge percentage of their lives is spent devoted to the entity that is CENTENE. Poor employee benefits ( health insurance) coverage - like seriously, Centene IS an insurance provider but it is an insult what they charge their own employees for premiums, and god forbid you have a family to cover as well - they really could do better. Pay careful attention to the title of what you are applying for. They will call someone who does analyst work a pharmacy technician so they can, with the pharm tech license requirement for the position, keep the salary range comparable to the pharmacy technicians in the area, not the analysts. The pharm techs in the area will certainly include retail pharmacy technicians ( cvs, rite aid, walgreens) who are notoriously underpaid. Beware. Fully expect to appreciate and respect your boss, they are most likely really hard workers and care about you - but know, that in order for them to keep their job, they have to sacrifice that connection to stay within the metrics the company has established.

column13:
Leadership focus culture is to promote work-life balance, to care about employee development, and to do the right thing.

Managers value self-reflective feedback and continuous improvement. As long as you are humble, recognize mistakes, and grow from them, you will be recognized.

Lots of opportunities for growth

Good industry to work in

Lots of remote work opportunities (part or full time even)
column14:
The culture they are trying to build is extremely inconsistent across departments and managers. Some teams apply the positive culture, while other managers do not.

Due to complexity of healthcare, takes a bit of time to get up to speed, and many times certain people are doing 80% of the work.

Industry is good to work in as healthcare is always needed, but with COVID CMS updates constantly force changes to systems.

High IT Security measures is both understandable but a nuisance to smooth work.

Company undergoing significant changes is a bit unstable at times

column14: - Mainly lack of enough staffing. COVID mandated cuts in 2020 cut some positions that it hurt to not have people in. Some staffing cuts due to mergers soon thereafter. Product over people

Psychological safety only in small pockets

 There are frequent cycles of low employee engagement and lots of talented people leaving.
Do not seem to understand how expensive and inefficient their current leadership style is.

column14:
They claim to be a technology company, but they use antiquated systems and practices. They are slow to adapt and change, which is actually a deeply ingrained trait of senior leadership.

Your work will likely go unnoticed and unrewarded. 

Tons of interdepartmental bickering and finger pointing. No one is interested in helping you unless they have an obligation to do so.

401k matching is shamefully low and deceptively advertised. They say "matches 50% of the first 6% that you contribute". This actually means 3%, so just say that. To make it worse, the vesting schedule is tiered over the course of 5 years.

Their insurance premiums are shamefully high. You can expect yearly increases as much as 20%.

Plummeting stock price.

The CEO is completely detached from the reality of normal working people. It's hard to respect a man that demands a 25 million dollar salary, and then tries to talk about income and social inequality in the country. It would be comical if it wasn't so sad.

Ultimately the company will only do the right thing for their employees when there is a legal obligation or liability.

column13: Some of the People Leaders are proficient in their Role; many on the job resources; Employee Assistance Program.

column13: -You can listen to your headphones while processing claims.\r\n-You get major Holiday's off
column14:
-Micro Managed.
-Unorganized.
-Mandatory OT on occasion, Including Saturday's from 8am-noon 
-No proper communication with analyst on job function.
-With consistent changes within the company, no one relays that to the analyst who are actually doing the work.
-Rushed floor training (you will learn new claims when on the floor and your lead or supervisor will rush and show you how it goes and assume you know how to solve the claim after showing you once or twice. The problem is, is that the claims are complex and not all the same. They cannot continuously help because of course, they have work of their own).
-Work flows (a list of directions to follow to help resolve the claim) are almost never up to date and are hard to follow.
-Upper management are super judgmental and uncomfortable to converse with and exist around.
-You will get audited by the state if you pay a claim too much or too little and depending on the amount, it can lead to termination. 
-Everyone is expected to move up as an analyst so that more claims can be processed. This new training includes a salary increase after it is complete. So, at the end of training, there will be a test and if you do not pass, you still have to process the claims when you get back out on the floor but you will be making the same amount as before the training, so you are expected to do twice the work for the same pay, because since you did not pass training, you will not making get the raise but are expected to do the work.
-So many more, a book load to write.

column14:
Two years of >7% inflation during a pandemic and this company grants a 3% "cost of living increase". They have effectively given everybody below VPs a 10% pay cut during the pandemic while cleaning house on Medicare sales.

They act like they care about employees but their actions are loud and clear -- you are nothing more than a peon here.

There is absolutely no indication at all that a new CEO will help. This now a multinational juggernaut that flies a giant banner about caring for people while doing the opposite for the people that make it happen.

Sold all my stock and I am leaving.

It is unconscionable.

Bad sr management
Unrealistic expectations for employees

Management wants to pick and choose what rules apply to salaried employees…for example we are expected to work unlimited hours per day….but at the same time told we have to be on a schedule like an hourly employee and we have to take PTO in 4 hour blocks even to leave an hour early. 
No room for growth professionally at all

column14:
-High turnover due to mediocre "first-line" management
-Job cuts are frequent
-Lots of job openings but many are for the call centers, both back office & front line
-Working for corporate in/near the HQ is very "clicky" meaning, if you're not a part of the right click, you get passed by on unique/fun/easy projects while you're stuck with the tedious & high stress stuff.
-Very stressful & I cannot express that enough (at least working under the call center in a back office role), if you cannot handle stress this is not the place for you
-Salary means you ARE going to work long hours, so if you don't ask for a high-enough salary it's not going to be worth the long hours you put (in perspective, a supervisor for business analysts makes around $90k in the midwest)

column14:
* Can't carry over vacation
* Only 4 sick days per year
* insurance options have just been gutted
* Legacy Centene employees are always the ones to get undesirable changes when we acquire new companies - for instance, a 1.5% raise this year to put us "in line" with Wellcare employees
* Legacy Centene employees are always the ones laid off
* If you're not part of the in crowd, forget promotions
* Will be required to go back to the office in person after working efficiently from home for almost 2 years
* They will change your office without warning, forcing you to drive miles further than where you were hired to work
*"Diversity and Inclusion" is only evident at the lowest pay grades

column13: Although they brag about diversity, nearly all of the top promotions and bonus pool allocation goes to men. They provide great care for customers, not for employees. They Will tell you you have a 20% bonus target as a senior Director – that’s not actually true, because they use a bell curve grading scale that makes it impossible for anyone but the pets to get that amount.
column14:
I have literally never been at a company that is so obvious about the fact that it doesn’t care about its employees. Especially for a healthcare company, the insurance benefits and maternity leave are terrible and not market.  They will only pay five days until the short term disability policy that YOU buy (which is capped at 60% of your pay) kicks in. And even that is only six weeks. Ever had a C-section? You can guess how that works out. 

When other Fortune 25 companies are offering four-six months paid, Centene gives you five days. Nothing if you are a co-parent. 

Centene should be embarrassed and ashamed of itself. “improving the health of the community” only applies if you don’t work there.

They also tell you you have a 20% bonus target as a senior Director – that’s not actually true, because they use a bell curve grading scale that makes it impossible for anyone but the pets to ever get that amount. Then, after you have killed yourself for a year to try and get an “exceeds”, they tell you “it’s a very high scale.” Literally a perfect review…but not enough.

column14:
- The culture is very resistant to change
- The culture is very antagonistic when crossing teams (not usually within teams that I have seen)
- The IT processes that are in place are very clumsy and time consuming. For example to open a port between two servers within the datacenter can easily take two months to complete.
- There are many undefined processes in IT as well, these are then rejected by default forcing escalation to leadership and weeks to get rather simple low risk items completed
- Change management process is very cumbersome. The simplest non intrusive change will typically require about 4 hours of just paperwork and you and at least one teammate working after hours to deploy, regardless if that's appropriate or not

I hate the direction this company has gone in. They have a vaccine mandate as a general condition of employment--regardless of whether you can work from home or have objections. They had a testing option, but that wasn't woke enough, so they removed it a few weeks after announcing it as an option.

They mention the vaccine mandate is in part as a responsibility to the community. It appears our CEO is mandating the vaccine for his is own virtue signal campaign.

I am looking for new opportunities for this reason alone. I'm not the only one.

HQ is a very conservative $$ driven company that doesn't really care about the welfare of its employees and sees them as cogs in the wheel. column13: This company has absolutely no positive points. Over the past year, they've fired thousands and thousands more have quit
column14: Executive team has no clue what is going on in the company. The attrition rate is at least 10 percent. Every day there are more people who are \"no longer with the company\". The benefits are basic, nothing special. Pay is below industry standard. Nearly everyone is looking for another job. The company is total chaos. They recently were found to have bilked states out of $1.25 billion. The same CEO and leadership team are still there. They are immoral and only care about how much money they can get through bonuses. They don't care about members or employees. An absolutely horrible place to work.

column13: Salary, I have nothing else…
column14: Leadership is not concerned with real transparency or truly fixing issues or concerns. They talk about accountability, but only when it applies to us direct reports and not for themselves or outside our team. There is no core training for any processes and employees are expected and encouraged to go to Google to find there information and ‘required’ to develop SOP’s for the work that is done. Talk about ‘on the job training’. Don’t look for any back up or support from management when dealing with other teams or departments…you won’t get any. They preach work-life balance yet don’t provide\u002Ffacilitate that in any way. Rework is just about as routine and common as our normal daily workload, which adds to the backlog of inventory, yet questions on why work isn’t done or request to work OT to get it done are scrutinized. Being understaffed only adds to the chaos. They foster a ‘bully’ environment and use constant pressure tactics such as email blast bombarding and last minute ‘touchbase’ meetings to advise how you’re not meeting expectations or standards, responding to their emails timely or enough times, take too long to do work and not reliable, yet have been told by this same management to keep up the good work many times. This managerial and workplace ‘gaslighting’ is designed to pad or build their case to fire you or to have you so stressed that you quit. The work and job itself isn’t that bad (minus the lack of training curriculum) I actually enjoy it, but the level of toxic leadership is mind boggling. It is by far the worst place I have worked and that’s saying a lot considering we’ve been WFH for a year and a half. I would not recommend working here to anyone.

column13: Recent mergers and acquisition brought with it, new knowledgeable leadership into the upper echelons, which resulted in new training programs and resources being introduced. Before the most recent M&A, nobody cared about (1)training employees or (2)diversity and inclusion or (3)listening to their employees.
column14:
# Unless you work at the headquarters or you know how to brown nose your way to the top, you are guaranteed to be stuck at the same role.
# HR process is a joke. The recruiters take their own time to process applications. Since the C-suite is not in favor of "work from home", your job application is ignored if you cannot relocation to the job location. Also, be prepared to negotiate your salary, the recruiters(hiring managers!! ) are known for lowballing your salary offer.
# Hypocrisy run rampant . C-suite tells you one thing at the townhalls, but does something else later. Leadership does not always have an open door policy, again, unless, you work for one of the newly acquired units. Turnover is high.
# Organic innovation is stagnant, the only way for them to grow is mergers or acquisitions.

column13: Centene is a big company
column14:
- Vaccine mandate: Comply or be fired by the end of 2021.
- Promotions: They promote from outside the company or not at all, internal talent is largely ignored (see next point). 
- Chaotic Leadership because of mergers: Acquired company leaders are brought in and everyone has a new direction for a year or so then it recycles and repeats, especially true for the specialty companies. Some get a new CEO almost yearly. Very poor management practice that results in their "new" vision getting ignored because they will be gone in a year anyway.
- Everyone is short-staffed and contractors are used to fill the gaps with less than desirable results.
- You will have a workload bigger than you can handle - ALWAYS.
- Centene is moving from a "Growth by acquisition/merger strategy" to a "streamlining/efficiency strategy" - that's a code word for even more workload and possible layoffs. 
- if you work in IT you will work almost ALL weekends and holidays - especially competent people. You might think you are getting paid well but after you add up all the hours it's not worth it.
- Before Covid Centene was deeply rooted in opposing work from home, Covid forced them to change, They WILL go back to requiring you in the office eventually - there is NO question about that.
- The bottom line? Centene is a frustrating employer, with frustrating bureaucratic slowness, frustrating & struggling technology, chaotic leadership with constantly changing vision, and a very high workload for competent employees.

column13: 1. Pay and benefits are very competitive for this location, depending upon your occupation.\n\n2. In some roles you will find a purpose which drives you forward. Given that this location contains several grievance\u002Fappeals teams, it's not difficult to find meaning in your work.
column14:
1. Leadership at the company's headquarters is cartoonishly toxic, and this carries over to upper management at this location. If you report to any senior leaders, expect to develop a relationship predicated on bullying and belittling rather than one based on mutual respect and a shared desire to complete business objectives. I have seen employees chastised to the point of tears, with one leader actually priding himself on having made certain people cry.

2. While the company is ramping up efforts to improve internal systems, software, and processes, much of the system architecture leaves a lot to be desired. Work processes (i.e., the documents on which new hired are trained and all employees must consult) are poorly maintained, and updates or deployments pushed out to production platforms are seldom communicated to ground-level employees. As a result, many employees feel as though their work is constantly changing and that they are not being informed when changes are made.

3. Virtually all of the work done here is reactive in nature. Again, as in con 2, the company is attempting to create work which is more proactive, such as process improvement initiatives. However, many ground-level employees feel that they are "constantly putting out fires", which is another way of saying that the work they do is rarely productive and rarely fulfilling. While most of the employees have "analyst" in their job title, reactive work does not require analytics and process improvement; instead, because of the time-sensitive nature of the situation, it requires quick, repetitive action. Also, work/life balance is this company has always been and continues to be a serious problem. If management feels that it is required, you will absolutely find yourself working both Saturday and Sunday, as well as extended hours during the weekdays. Supervisors or senior employees can expect to be called into work at any hour in response to an ask by management.

column13:
- I have seen career growth in 4 years at Centene that would have taken me 15 to 20 years anywhere else. Centene is very fast paced and rapidly growing. There are fires that need fighting and lots of growing pains, but this brings as much opportunity as challenge. Make yourself useful in the right area and you will go far. 
- I have been blessed with some incredible leaders, although not all areas of the company seem to be as lucky.
- Good benefits, good pay.
- Acceptable hours. This may not be true for all of IT, but in my area it's not common to work more than 45 hours a week unless someone just likes to do that.
column14: - Changing culture since the Healthnet merger. The values of the company overall have declined in the aftermath. \r\n- Some internal teams are very difficult to work with and take up to 6 weeks to respond to very simple requests or inquiries. \r\n- Competing direction given from upper management in IT.  While some are embracing Agile and even DevOps, others are being pushed to enforce restrictive, regimented processes and things that oppose the very nature of Agile and DevOps.

column13: Working with Centene as a developer is a lot of fun with the working environment. There is a lot of people who are dedicated to what they do, reliable in getting work done, but still able to have fun and unload while not losing focus. The people make development at Centene fun, and the work can be fun with the different and ever changing environments being worked on.
column14: The work can be frustrating because of the ever changing environment. Between that and the way security is ran, there is a lot of inefficiencies with no way around them. A project could be a sprint away from a demo and the team could be completely rearranged with only one person left on the team and everyone else thrown on other teams. The fact that the work is always fresh is fun for a few months, then it becomes a chore. Besides the hectic environmental changes, there are many things that can be frustrating such as development constraints with an ever increasing security footprint. The security is great when it doesn't interfere with coding, but when a developer cannot access github issues due to a new security incentive, it gets frustrating.

column14:
Other teams, and specifically managers and above on any team, have really poor work/life balance. The burnout comes around quickly. 
Strict business professional dress code (ties and panty hose are actually included in the official dress code).
Difficult to work from home (frowned upon).
Company is very disjointed and disorganized. Makes it very difficult to accomplish much. 
Company culture is very meeting-oriented, which contributes to the lack of work/life balance (spend all day in meetings, still have work to do at night).
Managers tend to micro-manage, which impedes productivity and decreases morale. 
Do not feel that leadership is open or transparent about the current state or future expectations of the company. Do not trust the CEO. Do not feel that Centene focuses enough on its mission to improve the health of members.

column14:
cliques. you could tell who was teacher's pet. HR seems to be fully invested in kissing the backside of management. 
I had read reviews on working here prior to accepting the position (which, sadly, I was expected to accept THE DAY IT WAS OFFERED. Because, of course, you are to show respect only to your new boss. They aren't invested in any of the professional relationships you have and therefore don't understand what giving notice even means.) And I was told to run, don't look back, et cetera. And I thought perhaps it was all because of some disgruntled ex-employees who couldn't run amock. 
Little did I know the reviews were _solid_. 
You'll only survive in this mess if you're ok with things proverbially blowing up all around you. If you are good at turning the other cheek, you're gonna go far, kid.

column14:
They take advantage of their employees, not paying the employees who have been around longer more money. 

Don’t even ask for a pay bump because the company will make every excuse why they will not !
And during the recruitment process they will offer you the least amount possible and say you are on “ a competitive salary “.

They don’t care if your about to be homeless just remember that. 

And during the holidays, they do not give out any bonuses but they definitely give you a cheap company gift. 
Not even a gift card but a REAL REAL CHEAP charger lol. Not even Walmart will sell. 
 
Forget even trying to get promoted or even transfer to a different department it’s like jumping through hoops. 

They do not really evaluate supervisors so prepare yourself, you will be taking the blame for a lot for them. 

Just... look at another job. Unless do you want a job that pretends to care ( fake).

column14: My tenure with this company was one of turmoil and high stress due to the work environment one is subjected to,  Good employees are not valued or respected.  Gross misconduct is a norm by the individual who is the manager of the department.   Disparaging\u002Fdivisive remarks about you are commonly made to your work peers which creates hostility and tension.  I was slandered by this individual on two occasions who told work peers that I did not like white people and I was racist. The manager is uninterested and unable to help you with any work issues because she does not know what you actually do even though she has been there for years. You often times pass by her office and she is texting on her iPhone while you are drowning & ironically should not have a phone out to protect HIPPA.  Current employees are afraid of retaliation or just try to hang on because after numerous supposedly anonymous surveys are filled out nothing happens.  By the time you walk out the door, you do not want to waste your time making a statement to HR who you by then realize is not there to help you. If you are truly friends with an individual you say, \"Run, Forest, run!\", if they are contemplating applying. I am a strong, mature individual but I got tired of the tomfoolery and was willing to take a pay cut to put myself in a better environment.  There it is folks, heed the warning or ignore.

column14: There are no words to  verbalize how toxic Centene is.  Hostile work environment, unobtainable work expectations, rampant cronyism with the hiring of friends\u002Ffellow co-workers (from pre Centene), inability to move or transfer within the company or promote (only their buddies get that option). Some get to work from home at times, others are blatantly told NO it's not company policy.  Weekly and then monthly \"one on ones\" with your manager to solidify the divide and separate mentality. People work out of fear of being walked out.  Most do not stay long enough to become vested (5 years). They simply give up. Culture is toxic and comes from the top down. Only 4 sick days per year.  Once that's exceeded, you are ripe to be written up or fired. Those who bring the best experience and education are the ones held back the most. HR is non-existent.  Trying to meet with them is nearly impossible, and they work only for risk management and prevention of lawsuits.  Yes, it's a job, but that's about it.  And if you want to work from home, run from here.  There are plenty of remote positions out there to choose from.

column14: Profits are the only driving force.  This company made their Billions off of taxes-\r\nThis company loves it when the economy is tanking. At a town hall meeting  a  little over a year ago the VP Speaking visibly showed disappointment when talking about the economy--At the time the economy was doing good, therefore membership was dropping.   The company deliberately declines providers claims, they down code provider claims without justification, when provider rates are increased they hold off implementing the correct rates, when providers are due large incentive checks, they date the checks the first of the month--deliver them a month later. (for a month they are earning interest off of Billions of dollars given to them by the state to give to the providers. It is  a very weak and cowardly company--The only way they can figure out how to increase profits is by putting the screws to the provider.  They can save money if they overhauled their internal processes. The company is extremely top heavy and few in management are capable of making decisions \"on their feet\"    They put up a façade that they care about their employees and want your suggestions.  Try and make a suggestion and you'll see it's a waste of your time.  You get no feedback.   Yearly Raises a minima-2%--they give  out incentives instead--this way there is no obligation to pay you more the next year or the year after that.

column13: The corporate campus is very nice.  Pay and benefits are reasonable.  The company continues to grow quickly and opportunities for development and exposure to different parts of the business are plentiful.
column14: Google scholarly articles on \"toxic work environments\" and you'll have a highly representative synopsis of the culture at the corporate office.  Too many managers are remnants of the days when the company was a smaller player.  Their ideas and ways of doing things simply no longer work.  Senior leadership provides no purpose or direction, other than stock price growth, Fortune ranking growth, campus expansion, etc.  Once the novelty of all these \"exciting\" things wears off, everyone is left to determine their own rationale for coming to work on a daily basis and the struggle for relevancy and resources has led to a really bad case of infighting.  There are certainly a lot of good people working there, but I've never experienced so many hostile and progress preventing people in my career.

column13: I have the highest regard for CEO Michael Neidorff.  He is a man of integrity and commitment to making the world a better place. His vision for providing proactive health care services to people in need has driven the company.
column14:
The company has grown too fast too quickly. In certain parts of the company (specifically the parts I experienced), the company is full of opportunists who spend far less time fixing problems than blaming others.  The good managers who are looking to fix problems get pushed out, and the opportunists get promoted.  As one employee told private my group, "I've got this thing all worked so that if it succeeds, I get all the credit, and if it fails, you guys get all the blame."

For the person (like most of my team) who does a good job, the environment is chaotic. We wear ourselves out trying to fight the latest fire, then come up with plans to make sure that the emergency never happens again, and a number of months later find that the same happened again because some manager disregarded all fail-safes and processes.

Not all parts of the company are like this, but I still tell all of my friends to stay away from this company.  There's a reason the company has a high burnout rate.

column14:
No work life balance.  Expect to work weekends and holidays.  Since Healthnet IT leadership as taken over work-life balance has gotten much worse (it was already bad).  They keep saying "it will get better" - been hearing that for years now - haven't taken time off for Christmas for three years and I have lost vacation because I couldn't use it.  Yes, they give you 3 weeks but good luck using it if you work in IT.   Another acquisition or another key implementation will always take priority over the lives of IT people.

Also not confident the IT leadership can navigate the future.  They seem a bit overwhelmed and lost.   Lots of corny jokes and lack of professionalism on group conference calls have replaced good solid old-school IT leadership since Healthnet has taken over.  I echo other reviews here, we were told Healthnet would follow the Centene way, but we were lied to, Healthnet has imposed their lackluster past performance management style on Centene IT.

If you have a young family don't work here - it's not worth the time away from your family.

You will also receive a decent severance package as long as you sign a document stating you will not sue them.\r\n\r\nExcellent Pre-school at a discounted price that is open 6am to 6pm so you can work almost 12 hours per day.
column14:
Too many to count and list here.  Major issues for me are:

•	No work/life balance
•	Bullying behavior from Managers - especially in the NurseWise division
•	Lack of responsible oversight from HR and Executive Management
•	Lack of training provided
•	Back-stabbing and favoritism are rampant
•	Working for a company that built state-of-the-art buildings and successfully took over a large part of Clayton by underhanded means.
•	Said Buildings, etc. were paid for with Medicaid Dollars.
•	While accruing time off, there is never a time you can actually take it.  You lose it because you can't carry it over to the next year.
•	Out-dated policies and procedures
•	No flexibility – hours, dress code, working remotely, etc.
•	Mentality that employees aren’t to be trusted and are not treated as the professionals they are.

column14: Stereo-typical \"Corporate America\" type culture. Office politics. Old school way of management. Office politics. Business formal attire. Office politics. I am an Applications Engineer, but the engineers and developers are undervalued and certainly underpaid. Centene has no real clue what the market value is for a Software Engineer. I feel bad for the young developers who come in expecting an \"IT Shop\", but in reality Centene is a \"Business Analyst\" shop. If you are an aspiring developer\u002Fsoftware engineer\u002Fprogrammer DO NOT COME TO CENTENE. I repeat DO NOT come to CENTENE. If anything, just interview and get an offer as leverage for another company's offer. Centene thinks they're \"agile\", but in reality they have no idea what being \"agile\" really means. Centene uses a \"corporate america\" idea of agile. Last but not least, office politics.

column13: Centene offers a good salary and potential bonuses. I would only recommend Centene to individuals who want to get experience and who have no outside of work commitments.
column14: Centene grew so fast it couldn't support existing business. As an IT Manager we were constantly shifting staff between new business and putting it continuous fires with existing business.  We were forced to make staff work 80 hours a week, nights, weekends...whatever it took. Everyday I came into a dozen new problems that cropped up overnight.  Centene is NOT the place to work if you have a family and want to keep it. In addition, the stress of the environment literally made me physically sick.  I ended up in the doctors office for high stress and exhaustion.  It took me months to get back to normal after leaving Centene.  In hindsight, I should have paid attention to similar reviews for working at Centene. I let the high salary persuade me. No salary is worth selling your soul and sacrificing your health.

column13: Nice building and decent co-workers
column14: Terrible Management and no structure

column13: Good salary, good health benefits, preventative wellness program, healthy inexpensive cafeteria food,  nurse on-site, opportunities to win tickets to sporting events (employee pays a $15 fee for baseball games at the Co. suite) and concerts, including the Fox theater
column14: Sometimes managers with \"get it done at all costs\" attitudes and who have poor people\u002Fline management skills are promoted very quickly; there is also a lot of \"good ole boy\" favoritism; the work\u002Fdeliverables is daunting---the overlap of projects can be overwhelming. Training is a \"ask for it and you might be approved basis\" else it's up to the employee to figure outtheir career path and request and obtain training, while still maintaining their exisiting job. If there is an HR issue brought to the attention of some managers, they will discipline the person bringing the issue to the attention of management. Do your job, get it done, \"d--- the torpedos, full steam ahead!\"

column13: Growth means more open positions and the capacity for lateral and upward movement.\r\nManaged Medicaid is needed by the States and with the implementation of health exchanges even more growth is probable.\r\nThe company invests in IT.
column14: Overwork is the norm.  Work life balance is poor.  Management can typically focus on the new business and by default not on the current customers.  Documentation of work processes and information sharing is poor.  There simply is not the time to do this.  Growth is outpacing the capacity of staff to do quality work, and management does not seem to have any accountability to find solutions that give employees the training, tools and bandwidth to succeed. Contracts are signed regardless of the capacity for the company to succeed at growing the business effectively. The management style is very top down, and blame is more the norm than is helpful.

column13: They will pay you over market values  jus to get you in I can’t even fill 20 characters for pros
column14: Your working for all white men and a token black who is irrelevant. They hire the people who will do their dirty work in management , if your gay or outspoken you will not be promoted a man told me out his own mouth our manager said he would never be a supervisor when our supervisor was begging him to apply . If you have style the dress code will change until you won’t be able to wear anything but a full suit . They not only discriminate by race but by age, sexual preference, personality, the supervisors idea of you is all you are. MB the head man  is someone’s nephew who doesn’t know how to run anything other than his mouth and point fingers at his managers who in turn point them at the workers  . Upper leaders outside the location had to come in and investigate . Half the department takes FMLA for stress. Put it like this you know it’s bad when ur manager tells the department before a luncheon  you all are the horses and on the farm the ducks go eat first so the horses don’t trample them . Don’t work here unless you absolutely have to .

column13: Benefits is the only pro I can think of
column14: No growth opportunity raises suck

column13: My colleagues are great people to work with. I admire all of them, and each bring skills that really help with our mission. Working downtown Seattle was fun at first, but that novelty wore off quickly. Pay is okay for the social service field.
column14: Unless you pay for your own parking, you'll be using public transit, which is unreliable and can take HOURS to get to\u002Ffrom work.  \"Leadership\" (what they call themselves) doesn't care about employee happiness, and they make that clear. Feel free to express your concerns to HR, but the only result will be getting targeted by management. There is no confidentiality between employees and supervisors, any private matter will be the next days gossip. Zero flexibility with your time. Zero work\u002Flife balance. This job could be performed remotely, like most insurance companies do, but coordinated care does not allow it for any reason. Unless you're \"leadership\", then rules don't apply. There are a lot of very talented people who work here, but they are quickly leaving because of the micromanaging, intense workloads and lack of trust with management. I could go on and on, but I hope this gets the point across.

column13: Pay and Benefits are on par with other fortune 500 companies
column14: The culture of the company is terrible.

column13:
* There is so much career growth within this company. When the company itself grows 53% in one year, the only way to go is up. 
* The Paid Time Off is awesome! over 3 weeks of Personal, Vacation and Sick time PLUS another 11 paid holidays! Not too many other companies in St. Louis offer that!
* The health benefits are the best I've even been enrolled in not to mention they get even better the Healthy Pathways program. 
* The healthcare industry will always be booming and in demand
* I have won Rams, Cardinals, and Blues tickets through Centene and they also offer tickets to win for comedy shows, concerts, etc. 
* Free Covered Parking!
* I work about 45 hours a week depending on what I have going on (not all groups operate the same way depending on the needs of the customers and our business)
* Bonus potential!!
* Dry Cleaning drop off/pick up and car cleaning services to make life more convenient.
* Tuition Reimbursement after 1 year of full-time employment

I feel very fortunate to work for this company. I have referred friends and family to work here and want the same great opportunities for them as I have here.
column14: The speed bumps in the parking garage are a pain. Centene employees have to park on the 6th floor and above so you need to add at least 5 minutes to your commute time.

column13:
- pay is good
- you will not have much contact with your supervisor or management
- you may be eligible to work from home after 90 days
- bonuses are available
- being successful does not require a lot of knowledge, skill, or experience
- your supervisor will likely not know what you do all day
column14:
- you can max-out your pay range and no longer receive annual salary increases
- when you do have contact with your supervisor or management, it will likely be a bad experience
- you have no support from supervisor or management to address problems or barriers
- earning a bonus requires doing extra things in addition to your job duties
- you will likely spend more time typing (documenting) than actually talking to or helping people
- your supervisor will likely not know what you do all day

column13: Pros are paid time off and benefits beginning on the first day of the month following your employment.
column14:
Top heavy management with inflated titles. Example: Four front line associates, one Supervisor and one Manager report to a Sr. Director. 
In other companies those positions would be  I, II, III, Lead, Manager.
The problem is, the titles have gone to the heads! Like all other reviews, management is unprofessional and does not manage. They are good at criticizing, making excuses and stroking their own egos.
The company is not filled with collaborative, brilliant, problem solvers, but instead associates looking to do as little as possible.

column13: Very competitive salary and benefits; big bonuses; great Clayton facility at headquarters with gym and cafeteria; fast paced and daily changes if you enjoy that kind of setting (I did) Company has seen tremendous growth, with this comes opportunity as well as many growing pains.
column14: Cutthroat job competition- you feel like you never stop interviewing for your current position, as layoff \"restructuring\" cycles occur typically at least 2x annually. This gives employees constant state of anxiety about job security and leaves state of leadership in constant flux. Had 5 bosses in 2 years here. Also creates huge gaps in function that the remaining employees have to fill in. (Expect long hours and frequently putting out fires that were likely preventable with appropriate resource allocation) CEO very firm on position of no telecommuting ever.

column13: Multiple locations across the U.S. and expanding into new markets
column14: Centene is too busy expanding to invest in their employees.  Centene’s talent acquisition team employs deceitful tactics when working with potential employees\u002Fapplicants.  This includes promoting Centene as a corporation that cares about their employees, offers a flexible work schedule, a balanced work-family life and competitive bonuses.  These promises were found to be lies.  Centene’s policies are stuck in the past.  They refuse to offer flexible work hours and demand an 8-5pm work schedule.  Salaried employees are not treated as such and making schedule adjustments to meet the necessary needs of a family (ie medical appointments) are frowned upon.  Bonuses are sparing and many excuses are provided by senior management as to why bonuses are not higher.  Furthermore, Centene does not take the time to find qualified persons for their management teams.  Managers are under qualified and extremely unprofessional.  Incidents such as racial slurs directed toward team members, inappropriate personal comments from directors and threats to “write-up” entire teams were only a few of the disgusting behaviors seen by management while employed by Centene.  Sadly, when reports were made to Human Resources little if anything was done.  This is not an organization of integrity.

column13: Fast growing and some room for advancement
column14:
For Medicaid recipients, the quality of the majority of Centene health plans is poor and not representative of a leader in the field. The number of contract terminations and sanctions against the company are disturbing. Plan presidents have commented in the past that it is cheaper to pay the sanction than to fix the related problem. Instead of trying to do quality improvement, the campany focuses on trying to get the fine reduced that is charged for a sanction.

For the local Clayton community, Centene purchased the land which had a community garden. The garden was removed to put up another building. This building is for Centene University. The CEO commented that members of the community should get out of the way of progress.

For employees, Centene does not teat employees fairly or consistently. Those in the inner circle ignore HR policies and give extra vacation time to those who they like. Other employees have their vacation requests ignored and neither approved not denied. Vacation time is accrued at a very slow pace over the year and is then taken away if not used that year. In Missouri, Centene will not pay you for your unused vacation. In California, state law requires that Centene pays employees for unused vacation.

Whether for members, the community, or for employees, Centene only does the right thing when required to by state governments.

column13: As someone who worked her way from a 3-month contract to a 2-year full time position, I would say Centene definitely recognizes hard work and rewards you for it with increased responsibility and opportunities for promotion. I started on a decent hourly rate which was soon raised without my even having to ask. You absolutely won't go unappreciated here so long as you're a hard worker.
column14: While there are opportunities for upward movement, they take time. You have to be willing to commit years to this company if you want to move up a few levels, but I think most places are that way.\r\nEnrollment periods are stressfully busy, slower periods can drag on, but if you're detail oriented and driven you'll make it all balance.

column13: its okay, they have good benefits
column14: they dont train you at all. wack

column13: As a long time employee, I have observed over the last couple of years Centene placing a high priority in hiring exceptional leaders to help us go to the next level as an organization.  These leaders have focused on engagement, work-life balance, caring about employees, and process and procedures.  The IT organization is not the same one of a couple years ago.
column14: A formal work-from-home policy does not exist.  In addition, we need to lighten up as a corporation in order to attract the upcoming innovators within the area who are essential for growing our IT capabilities.  In addition, competitive and\u002For attractive perks are also necessary.

column13: - Unlike most companies nowadays, Centene's policy is to do most job functions inhouse, instead of outsourcing them to an offshore company\r\n- Good innovation, but depends on which department you work for\r\n- Good pay and benefits
column14: Growth opportunities are location based. They prefer to hire people from low to medium income neighborhoods, instead of major cities. If your position happen to be 'grandfathered' in from a major city, you are practically stuck with no upward mobility.

column13: Salary, benefits, great coworkers, CEO and leadership with integrity, challenges, Agile\u002FSCRUM-oriented
column14: Numerous meetings, in-office first mentality (not fond of WFH), too many communication channels, too many corporate trainings that don't add value, positions not refilled

column13: Centene cares about it's members. They put a lot of emphasis on Employee Engagement. They provide a lot of training classes for personal growth and development. There is also a good system in place for annual reviews and bonuses. There are a lot of great employees here who have a lot of knowledge and passion that you can learn from. Great benefits!
column14: Although there is emphasis on obtaining Employee Engagement, I don't think the follow through is that great.
